title: Spring forces - adding a third parallel spring

content.question: A block is initially held up by a combination of two identical springs, each with a spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>. The combined two-spring system has an equivalent spring constant of <math alttext="k sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. A third identical spring is then added to the system, as shown in Figure <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>. What is the equivalent spring constant <math alttext="k sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mstyle></math> of the three-spring system in terms of <math alttext="k sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="one third times k sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="two thirds times k sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>
<math alttext="three halves times k sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="three halves times k sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
